issues.description: The Person model's field visibility differs between the template (+ problem UML) and the solution. The template's Person class (and the UML in the problem statement) declares the fields as private with public getters/setters, while the solution's Person class makes the same fields public (while still keeping getters/setters). This is a structural visibility mismatch: the problem statement's UML uses '-' (private) for Person fields, the template code uses private fields, but the solution exposes them as public. This inconsistency can confuse students inspecting the reference solution (they may wonder whether fields should be private and accessed via getters/setters or directly), and it contradicts the encapsulation implied by the UML and template.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the Person fields' visibility consistent across artifacts. Prefer restoring encapsulation to match the UML and template: change the solution's public fields back to private (keep the existing public getters and setters). For example, in solution_repository/src/common/java/de/tum/in/ase/eist/model/Person.java change 'public UUID id;' etc. to 'private UUID id;' (and likewise for firstName, lastName, birthday). This preserves the intended design (encapsulation) and removes confusion.

issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2 description) incorrectly says that PersonController methods take a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter, while both the template and the solution define and use Consumer<List<Person>> for the PersonController methods. This mismatched identifier (Note vs Person) refers to the same conceptual consumer parameter and can confuse students about the expected method signatures and the type they should use when implementing/testing the PersonController.
issues.suggested_fix: Change the problem statement text to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (instead of Consumer<List<Note>>) in the Part 2 description so it matches the PersonController method signatures in the template and solution. E.g. replace "Each method takes a `Consumer<List<Note>>` parameter" with "Each method takes a `Consumer<List<Person>>` parameter".
